did.abstract: Carey McWilliams (1905-1980) was a writer, lawyer, journalist, lecturer, activist, as well as Chief of the California Division of Immigration and Housing (1938-1942) and editor of The Nation (1955-1975). The collection contains personal diaries, scrapbooks, manuscripts, publicity materials, and assorted correspondence and research files related to McWilliams's life and career.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Iris McWilliams, 1982 and 1995.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Carey McWilliams Papers (Collection 1319). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The papers of Carey McWilliams do not survive as a whole in any one place. Both during his lifetime and after his death, parts of the papers were disposed of at various times by gift or sale. The Bancroft Library at the University of California, Berkeley, has custody of many of the manuscripts for his books and the UCLA Department of Special Collections has several collections in addition to Collection 1319 which were originally part of the McWilliams papers, the largest of which is Collection 1243 comprising research materials on farm labor in California and the problems of the Mexican American. This material was donated to the Library in 1952 as part of the John Randolph Haynes and Dora Haynes Foundation Collections. In addition, the major part of the following three groups of papers purchased by the Library in the 1950s, derived from McWilliams originally:

list.item: #278: Mary (Hunter) Austin collection. Correspondence, manuscripts, articles and clippings by and about Mary (Hunter) Austin. (ca. 150 pieces).

#277: Ambrose Bierce collection. Correspondence, pictures, clippings, notes, and other material by and about Bierce, assembled by McWilliams for his biography, Ambrose Bierce (New York, A.C. Boni, 1929). (ca. 500 items).
#276: George Serling collection. Correspondence, manuscripts, articles, clippings and ephemera by and about George Serling. (ca. 125 items).

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Collection 1319 was donated to the Library in 1982 and in 1995 by McWilliams' widow, Iris McWilliams. At the time of accessioning, the papers were given preliminary processing by Manuscripts Division staff based on lists compiled by the donor. Andrea Eitsert with assistance from Laurel McPhee rehoused, described, and arranged the collection into series levels to facilitate enhanced access to materials, and created a new finding aid, 2006.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Carey McWilliams was born December 13, 1905 in Steamboat Springs, Colorado. He completed his Juris Doctorate from the University of Southern California in 1927. From 1927-1938, McWilliams was an attorney at the law firm Black, Hammack in Los Angeles. In 1938, he was appointed as chief of Division of Immigration and Housing of the State of California, a position he kept until 1942. During the period from 1945-1955, he began his long association with The Nation, becoming successively contributing editor, associate editor, and then editorial director. From 1955-1975, he was The Nation's editor. In addition to his editorial duties, McWilliams was a prolific lecturer and writer, speaking on many subjects and contributing articles and essays to numerous publications. After his retirement from The Nation, he continued to write a regular column for that publication. His monographs include Ambrose Bierce, a biography (1929); Louis Adamic and shadow America (1935); Factories in the field: the story of migratory farm labor in California (1939); Ill fares the land: migrants and migratory labor in the United States (1942); Brothers under the skin (1943); Prejudice: Japanese-Americans, symbol of racial intolerance (1944); Southern California country: an island on the land (1946); A mask for privilege: anti-Semitism in America (1948); North from Mexico: the Spanish-speaking people of the United States (1949); California: the great exception (1949); Witch hunt: the revival of heresy (1950); and his autobiography The education of Carey McWilliams (1979). In the late 1970s, McWilliams was briefly a Regents Lecturer at the University of California Riverside and then taught one quarter at the University of California Los Angeles in the History Department. He died of cancer at the age of 74 on June 27, 1980 in New York, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of Carey McWilliams's bound volumes, manuscripts, publicity and criticism, printed materials, and assorted correspondence and research files related to his life, writings, publishing and lecture activities, and political causes. Files include personal diaries, scrapbooks, notebooks, handwritten and typed notes, press releases, leaflets, pamphlets, articles, clippings, professional and personal correspondence, and outlines and manuscript drafts. These files reflect McWilliams's varied professional interests, including racial minorities, migrant farm workers, civil liberties, the Cold War, McCarthyism, the press, American politics, literature, religious cults, and the West (notably California and Colorado). The manuscript series documents McWilliams's original work in different genres: addresses, articles, reviews, fiction, and monographs. The collection also contains materials related to McWilliams's tenure as the Chief of the California State Division of Immigration and Housing (DIH), and a copy of the file compiled on him by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Bound volumes, 1921-1980 (24.5 boxes)
Correspondence and research files, 1896-1982 (38 boxes)
Division of Immigration and Housing, 1939-1964 (1 box)
Federal Bureau of Investigation, 1940-1980 (1 box)
Lecture files, 1939-1980 (2 boxes)
Manuscripts, 1896-1981 (18 boxes)
The Nation, 1894-1980 (3 boxes)
Printed materials, 1925-1980 (1 box)
Publicity and criticism, 1929-1980 (1.5 boxes).

Carey McWilliams papers, 1921-1980 (Collection BANC MSS C-H 46) . Available at Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley.
Carey McWilliams miscellaneous papers, 1941-1945 . Available at Hoover Institution Archives, Stanford, CA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
This series contains assorted types of bound volumes. Arranged in subseries A-D as follows:
A. Diaries, 1922-1980 (7.5 boxes)
B. Financial ledgers, 1945-1980 (4 boxes)
C. Notebooks, 1921-1972 (2 boxes)
D. Scrapbooks, 1923-1949 (11 boxes).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains McWilliams's personal diaries. A partial index is located at the beginning of the subseries. Preservation photocopies of the diaries from 1924, 1927, and 1929-33 are located in box 32. All other items are arranged in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Loose notebook papers with index to diaries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notebook contains a partial index to the diaries from the years 1945-1975, intermixed with a general index/timeline for contemporary events in "bound volumes" (unidentified) 1951-1974. Also contains miscellaneous notes and quotations, with subjects including: 1930s, 1940s, Legislative Investigation Report (1938 December 12), Dan Biderman, Clay Steinman, HUAC, Hamby, F.O. Matthiessen, Moynihan, Memo of Conversation Angus Cameron (1976 August 13), and book reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains notebooks of holograph and typewritten notes, reading lists, outlines, and quotations. It also includes a typewritten bibliography of McWilliams's published work from 1924-1972. Items are arranged in approximate chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes and quotations dated 1878-1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typewritten bibliography of McWilliams's published works from 1924-1972; and a loose-leaf, handwritten reading list dated 1924.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two groupings of loose notebook pages. First group consists of Division of Immigration and Housing appearances, a reading list, and typed notes on subjects including Nipomo, migratory schools, Korean residents of California, Filipinos, Imperial Valley, and agricultural strikes. Second group contains handwritten and typed reading lists and quotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extensive typed notes about and quotations from published articles (The Nation, The Outlook, Saturday Evening Post, etc.). Reviews and notes on books, principally titles on political and social science. Cover is illustrated with a clipping showing the view of Los Angeles from a hill garden.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes and quotations dated from 1889-1936. The primary subject is Southern California. Also contains loose leaves and many blank pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes and quotations dated from 1904-1941. Subjects include the Philippines, Puerto Rico, and racism against the Chinese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes and quotations with references to 1871-1899. Subjects include the Spanish-American War and Ambrose Bierce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten quotations from New Republic, The Nation and other publications dated 1886-1931.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed notes and clippings of quotations in alphabetical order by person, and handwritten notes. Labeled "Quotes from writers" on cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed notes, quotations, and outlines. Primary subject is racism, including African Americans, Japanese-Americans, and the South. Titles of outlines include "Race relations in tomorrow's America," "Reaction to Smith vs. Allright," "A practical solution for America's race problem," "Orientals in American life," and "Japanese-Americans face the future," among others. Also includes notes from an interview with Jacob Kravitz of the Jewish Welfare Federation in Dallas, dated 1946 March 30.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five pages of handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains scrapbooks of clippings from a variety of publications, many mentioning McWilliams or his work. Some scrapbooks also include clippings of articles and essays written by him. Items are arranged by the original scrapbook number assigned to each volume by McWilliams himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings that mention Factories in the Field. Clippings come from numerous publications, mostly newspapers, including some from The Nation and a few written by McWilliams. Other subjects include migrant labor, Grapes of Wrath, and books. Ca. 60 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications (mostly newspapers) that mention Factories in the Field. Other subjects include migrant labor, Grapes of Wrath, and books. Ca. 70 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily clippings and some assorted printed materials. Majority of clippings by or about McWilliams and/or his work. Clippings come from numerous publications, mostly newspapers (including a few from The Nation and PM). Subjects include While You Were Gone, Prejudice: Japanese Americans, Symbol of Racial Intolerance, Primer for White Folks. Ca. 30 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily clippings and some assorted printed materials. Majority of clippings by or about McWilliams and/or his work. Clippings come from numerous publications, mostly newspapers, a few from The Nation and Pacific Weekly. Subjects include Louis Adamic, fascism, "yellow peril," anti-Semitism, the press. Ca. 50 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily newspaper clippings. Majority of clippings mention McWilliams's work as Chief of the Division of Immigration and Housing. Clippings come from numerous publications, including 2 loose leaf articles from NM. Subjects include farm labor, migrant labor, Factories in the Field, Grapes of Wrath, and the Bancroft Debates. Ca. 70 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings and some assorted printed materials. Majority of clippings mention McWilliams or his work. Clippings come from numerous publications, mostly newspapers. Subjects include farm labor, migrant labor, Factories in the Field (reviews), race relations, aliens, Sleepy Lagoon Defense Committee, Humphrey Cobb, Wage Rate Hearings. Ca. 90 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newspaper clippings from numerous publications. Subjects are farm and migratory labor, and the Orange County strikes. Ca. 50 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, from numerous publications, of reviews of Ill Fares the Land. Many loose clippings in addition to scrapbook's ca. 40 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications (mostly newspapers) and a few assorted printed materials. These clippings mention McWilliams's work as Chief of the Division of Immigration and Housing and/or as author of Factories in the Field. Subjects are primarily farm and migratory labor and housing. Contains 2 loose leaves in addition to scrapbook's ca. 60 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications, mostly reviews of (or articles touching on the issues of) Prejudice: Japanese Americans, Symbol of Racial Intolerance. Also includes a few articles written by McWilliams for NM and The Nation. Ca. 70 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily clippings from numerous publications and some assorted printed materials, including an attestation of McWilliams's membership in The Order of the Coif (a national honor society). Main subjects are George Sterling, and the New Regionalism. Also contains typewritten poetry manuscripts by Sterling, clippings of published poems and literary articles and reviews by McWilliams. Contains loose leaves in addition to scrapbook's ca. 50 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newspaper clippings from numerous publications. Main subject is labor, including farm labor and wages. Ca. 50 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications (mostly newspapers) that mention Factories in the Field. Other subjects include migrant labor, Grapes of Wrath, and books. Ca. 50 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications of reviews of Southern California Country. Includes 3 manuscripts of reviews (2 by George Stiller, 1 by Lawrence Clark Powell). Contains additional loose clippings (2 envelopes). Ca. 60 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, including many articles written by McWilliams for California Curiosa, Tides West, New Republic and other publications. Subjects include Ambrose Bierce, California, and elections. Ca. 70 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, primarily literary reviews by McWilliams for numerous publications. Also contains loose leaves in addition to scrapbook's ca. 80 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, some assorted printed materials, and 2 loose leaves (1 from a manuscript about a journalist White). McWilliams wrote many of these articles, which appeared in numerous publications including American Mercury, Pacific Weekly, The Nation, News of the World. Subjects include Ambrose Bierce, farm labor, Nazis, Fascism, and the Congress of Western Writers. Ca. 50 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily newspaper clippings from numerous publications. Majority of clippings mention McWilliams's work as Chief of the Division of Immigration and Housing. Subjects include farm labor, migrant labor and housing, Factories in the Field, and George Kidwell's statements. Ca. 60 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications. Most are reviews of Brother Under the Skin, but a few address the Zoot Suit Riots. Also includes a list of newspaper and magazine advertising on McWilliams. Contains a few loose leaves in addition to scrapbook's ca. 40 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings from numerous publications and some assorted printed materials, including a few articles written by McWilliams for The New Republic and The Nation. Many clippings mention McWilliams's work as Chief of the Division of Immigration and Housing. Subjects include Prejudice: Japanese Americans, Symbol of Racial Intolerance, Ill Fares the Land, farm labor, and housing. Ca. 80 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings/reviews of Ill Fares the Land from British and Irish newspapers. 8 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
This series contains McWilliams's general correspondence and research files, and comprises the bulk of the collection. Arranged in subseries A-D as follows:
A. Files on people, 1912-1982 (11 boxes)
B. Files on subjects, 1914-1982 (20 boxes)
C. General correspondence, 1923-1980 (6 boxes)
D. Publisher correspondence, 1942-1980 (1 box).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains McWilliams's extensive research and correspondence files relating to specific individuals with whom he corresponded, or who were research subjects for his writings. The files contain correspondence (by or about the person named on the file), clippings, ephemera, and assorted printed materials. Arranged alphabetically by surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains McWilliams's extensive research files relating to specific topics, issues, or concepts. The files contain correspondence, handwritten and typed notes, press releases, leaflets, articles, and clippings. Some of the folders contain information about his work and political activities, most notably in the folders entitled "Red-Baiting." McWilliams's original file names were maintained during processing wherever possible, though some were altered to ensure consistency and collocation. Arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains McWilliams's main body of personal and professional correspondence that was not originally filed by him in folders under the names of individual people or topics. Additional correspondence may be found throughout the collection, particularly in the files on people (see Subseries 2A), his publisher correspondence (see Subseries 2D), his lecture files (see Series 5), his The Nation files (see Series 7, box 86), and within his papers relating to the publication of major monographs (see Subseries 6E). McWilliams kept his original correspondence files in an approximate chronological fashion. To preserve the integrity of the original order of these materials, this subseries was arranged chronologically. The names of important or interesting correspondents are given at the folder level.

scopecontent.p: This series contains papers, reports and manuscripts relating to McWilliams's tenure as Chief of the Division. Other DIH materials may be found in his notebooks (Subseries 1C, box 17, folder 3), the scrapbooks (Subseries 1D), the monograph files (Subseries 6E, box 82, folders 5-11), and within the general correspondence files (Subseries 2C, box 25, folders 11 and 12). Files are in chronological order, with the exception of undated materials, which are filed alphabetically at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of one folder of correspondence related to McWilliams's Freedom of Information Act requests for information from his CIA and FBI files, and eight folders of photocopied documents from McWilliams's FBI file, arranged in chronological order. The files include reports, transcripts by informants, clippings, and statements of fact related to McWilliams's activities. McWilliams's own research file on the FBI may be found in the general subject files (Subseries 2B, box 73, folder 1).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, publicity materials, receipts, and agency files related to McWilliams's lecture appearances. The correspondence includes lecture offers and letters of thanks. Other materials mentioning McWilliams's lecture appearances may be found in the publicity and criticism files (Series 9), the general subject files (Subseries 2B, box 40, folder 10), and in the general correspondence files (Subseries 2C). Typewritten manuscripts and outlines of actual lectures may be found in the Division of Immigration and Housing files (Series 3), and in the manuscripts subseries for addresses and lectures (Subseries 6A). Files are arranged alphabetically, then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
This series contains typewritten manuscript drafts and outlines by McWilliams, along with supporting materials. Arranged in subseries A-E as follows:
A. Addresses and lectures, 1937-1979 (7.5 boxes)
B. Articles and essays, 1927-1981 (5 boxes)
C. Book reviews, ca. 1941-1978 (.25 box)
D. Fiction, ca. 1920s-1948 (.25 box)
E. Monographs, 1896-1980 (5 boxes). Manuscripts composed for McWilliams's role as Chief of the Division of Immigration and Housing can be found in the DIH files (Series 3).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains manuscript drafts and outlines of articles and essays by McWilliams, along with assorted supporting materials. The manuscripts include editorials, memoranda, letters to the editor, forewords to books, a "Dossier" (which summarizes his education, professional activities, and political attitudes), and an annotated copy of his last article, "Los Angeles: a very special city." Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains manuscripts, correspondence (from critics, fans, and publishers), research materials, reviews, and legal and financial documents related to the writing and publication of McWilliams's books. Additional reviews of his monographs may be found in the publicity and criticism files (Series 9) and in his scrapbooks (Subseries 1D). Additional correspondence related to his books may be found in the correspondence files (Subseries 2C and 2D). For research materials possibly compiled for The Education of Carey McWilliams, see the general subject files (Subseries 2B, box 65, folders 1 and 2) and The Nation files (Series 7, box 87, folders 2-5). Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, clippings, general subject files, and assorted printed materials that were originally labeled by McWilliams as files specifically relating to The Nation. Other materials related to The Nation are found throughout the collection, especially in the correspondence and research files (Subseries 2A, 2B, 2C), and in the manuscript files (Subseries 6A, 6B, 6C). Arranged alphabetically, then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Freda Kirchwey, C. Wright Mills, Helen Alfred, and others. Also includes memoranda (one listing articles appearing in The Nation that were not "soft on communism"), 3 letters from John F. Kennedy, a letter from William Wyler, and a statement in Spanish from Diego Rivera giving The Nation permission to use his mural, "Gloriosa Victoria."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With B. J. Widick, Arnold H. Maremont, and others. Also includes memoranda and clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Arnold H. Maremont. Also includes memoranda, a clipping, a letter from Saul Bass, and a letter from George Kirstein concerning limited partners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With William H. Fitzpatrick, Jacques Calmy, Everett Mendelsohn, and Cyril J. Bath. Also includes letters, memoranda, and clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Also includes memoranda and clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Karl M. Ruppenthal. Also contains letters (including one to Ralph Ingersoll in which McWilliams explains The Nation's "specialness"), and memoranda (including one on editorial policy, and 2 to James Storrow).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With James Storrow, Vic Bernstein, Willie D. Jacobs, and David B. Lord. Also contains memoranda, and letters (including recommendations from Lawrence Clark Powell and John J. Clopine).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With George Salzman, and Rita Lawrence. Also includes letters, and McWilliams's memorandum on "night thoughts" about The Nation (9 pgs.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Peter Miller, James Storrow, Blair Clark, James Dembin, Richard D. Hongisto, and Kingsley Widmer. Also includes letters and memoranda.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Hamilton Fish, James and Linda Storrow, and between Milton Viorst and Storrow. Also includes letters (1 from Blair Clark to Cesar Chavez), and a statement of editorial content by Viorst.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Jake Zeitlin, and Studs Terkel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Stanley Mosk, Lillie Shultz, and Bernard Nossiter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Theodore Roszak, and James M. Cain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Charles Frankel concerning a possible international conference to be sponsored by The Nation for the editors of critical opinion journals. Also includes 2 letters, a typewritten outline, a press release, 3 leaflets (2 concerning The Nation's 100th birthday and the other a Nation anthology), articles (3 by McWilliams: "The Nation and the Magazine of Opinion," "Who Says So?" and "One Hundred Years of The Nation"), and clippings mostly referring to The Nation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters (primarily concerning the federal indictments of Harvey Matusow, R. Lawrence Siegel, Hadassah R. Shapiro, and Martin Solow), a memo from McWilliams to M.R. Werner about censorship in the publishing industry, handwritten and typed notes, an annotated manuscript draft fragment, clippings, and assorted printed materials concerning a 1952 dinner forum of The Nation Associates on Arab-Israel Peace (including an untitled manuscript). Also contains McWilliams's articles: "Goldwaterism: The New Ideology," "High Noon in the Cow Palace," "The Last Optimist," and "The Freda Kirchwey I Knew." This material was possibly compiled for a chapter in The Education of Carey McWilliams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (with Samuel Shapiro and Norman Birnbaum, and Mrs. Walter H. Hatch), letters, a list of labor articles, a pamphlet, leaflets, extensive handwritten and typed notes, and articles. Includes 2 letters and a typewritten poem from John Ciardi. This material was possibly compiled for a chapter in The Education of Carey McWilliams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 pamphlets ("Alternative Perspectives on Vietnam" and "Hughes for Senate"), a paper by Dr. Frederick Schuman entitled, "The Neuroses of The Nations," and newspaper clippings. This material was possibly compiled for a chapter in The Education of Carey McWilliams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A press release, and clippings. Includes a McWilliams's review of a book on the Rosenbergs. This material was possibly compiled for a chapter in The Education of Carey McWilliams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes the Second Thoughts column.

scopecontent.p: An invitation to the dinner forum, and clippings.

did.unittitle: The Nation Institute Conference on American Foreign Policy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (with Rita Lawrence, George McGovern, Eliot Macy, and Nancy Reeves), letters of thanks from McWilliams to those who participated in the conference, a copy of the speech given by Martin Luther King, Jr., a typewritten manuscript of Malcolm W. Browne's remarks, as well as a copy of Eugene J. McCarthy's remarks entitled, "Moral Aspects of the War in Vietnam." Also includes McWilliams's typewritten outline for the preliminary meeting and a copy of his address "The New Constituencies." This conference took place on February 25, 1967. (See also box 67, folder 18)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The report is for the period from August 1, 1965 to August 1 1966. Also includes a 1958 memorandum from McWilliams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lists of limited partners, contacts, awards, pieces on conservation, references to Red China, and signed articles dealing with Vietnam. Also includes quotations, bibliographies, a memo on editorial policy, and McWilliams's European work schedules.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series primarily consists of clippings of articles, reviews and reprints written by McWilliams that appeared in a variety of publications. Some pamphlets are included. Additional published writings by McWilliams may be found in the scrapbooks (Subseries 1D), his files on people (Subseries 2A), his general subject files (Subseries 2B), and The Nation files (Series 7). Arranged in chronological order, with undated materials at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains assorted printed materials (such as clippings, leaflets, and press releases) that are about, or mention, McWilliams and/or his work. It also contains materials related to honors and recognitions he received, and, contrastingly, accusations of communist leanings or protests over his appearances. Other publicity and criticism materials may be found in the lecture files (Series 5), The Nation files (Series 7, box 88, folders 5 and 6), the Division of Immigration and Housing files (Series 3, folder 6), the monograph files (Subseries 6E), and the scrapbooks (Subseries 1D). Files are in chronological order, with undated materials at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assorted printed materials relating to the University of Southern California Honorary Doctor of Laws Degree McWilliams received on June 8th, 1974. Includes correspondence, twenty-two 8 x 10 black and white photographs, six 3.5 x 5 color photographs, seven color slides, three black and white negatives, the commencement program, leaflets, and clippings.
